001package squidpony;
002
003import regexodus.MatchResult;
004import regexodus.Pattern;
005import regexodus.Replacer;
006import regexodus.Substitution;
007import regexodus.TextBuffer;
008
009import java.util.HashMap;
010
011/**
012 * Helps handle formation of messages from a template, using correct pronouns and helping handle various idiosyncrasies
013 * in English-language text. You call the static method
014 * {@link #transform(CharSequence, String, NounTrait, String, NounTrait)} (or one of its overloads) with a template that
015 * has specific placeholder glyphs, along with a user name, optional target name, user NounTrait (an enum in this class)
016 * to specify how the user should be addressed, including their gender, optional target NounTrait, and possibly extra
017 * terms that should be inserted. The placeholder glyphs are usually followed by a specific word that is conjugated in
018 * the template for the first-person case, and will be changed to fit the NounTrait for the user or target. For example,
019 * you could use "@Name hit$ ^ for ~ damage!" as a message. You could transform it with user "Heero Supra", userTrait
020 * NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR, target "the beast", targetTrait NounTrait.UNSPECIFIED_GENDER, and extra "10" to get
021 * the message "You hit the beast for 10 damage!". You could swap the user and target (along with their traits) to get
022 * the message "The beast hits you for 10 damage!" You can handle more complex verbs in some cases, such as "@I hurr$$$
023 * to catch up!" can be transformed to "You hurry to catch up!" or "He hurries to catch up!". The rules are fairly
024 * simple; @word conjugates a specific word from a list to the correct kind for the user, while ^word does a similar
025 * thing but conjugates for the target. Between 1 and 3 $ chars can be used at the end of verbs to conjugate them
026 * appropriately for the present tense when the verb is performed by the user (with just $) or alternately the target
027 * (if the $ chars are preceded by a ^), while @s, @ss, @sss, ^s, ^ss, or ^sss can be added at the end of nouns to
028 * pluralize them if appropriate. Using one $ or s will add s or nothing, as in the case of hit becoming hits, using two
029 * $ or s chars will add es or nothing, as in the case of scratch becoming scratches, and using three will add ies or y,
030 * as in the case of carry becoming carries. Some unusual pluralization forms are handled; @usi will turn octop@usi into
031 * octopus or octopi, and radi@usi into radius or radii, while @fves will turn el@fves into elf or elves, or dwar@fves
032 * into dwarf or dwarves.
033 * <br>
034 * The words you can put after a @ or ^ start with a small list and can be added to with
035 * {@link #learnIrregularWord(String, String, String, String, String, String, String)}. The initial list is: name,
036 * name_s, i, me, my, mine, myself, am, have, do, haven_t, don_t, or any of these with the first char capitalized (meant
037 * for words at the start of sentences). The non-word shortened terms "m" and "ve" can be used for "I'm" and "I've",
038 * respectively, as well as "you're" and "you've", plus "he's" for "he is" and "he's" for "he has". Most of the rest
039 * conjugate as you would expect; @me will become him, her, it, them, you, or still more forms depending on userTrait.
040 * You can also use @ or ^ on its own as an equivalent to @name or ^name.
041 * <br>
042 * Examples:
043 * <br>
044 * {@code Messaging.transform("@I @am @my own boss@ss.", "unused", changingTrait)}
045 * <ul>
046 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR}, this returns "I am my own boss."</li>
047 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL}, this returns "We are our own bosses."</li>
048 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR}, this returns "You are your own boss."</li>
049 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL}, this returns "You are your own bosses."</li>
050 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.NO_GENDER}, this returns "It is its own boss."</li>
051 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.MALE_GENDER}, this returns "He is his own boss."</li>
052 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.FEMALE_GENDER}, this returns "She is her own boss."</li>
053 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.UNSPECIFIED_GENDER}, this returns "They are their own boss."</li>
054 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.ADDITIONAL_GENDER}, this returns "Xe is xis own boss."</li>
055 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.SPECIAL_CASE_GENDER}, this returns "Qvqe is qvqis own boss."</li>
056 *     <li>When changingTrait is {@code NounTrait.GROUP}, this returns "They are their own bosses."</li>
057 * </ul>
058 * {@code Messaging.transform("@Name spit$ in ^name_s face^s!", userName, userTrait, targetName, targetTrait)}
059 * <ul>
060 *     <li>When userTrait is {@code NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR}, targetName is {@code "the goblin"}, and
061 *     targetTrait is {@code NounTrait.MALE_GENDER}, this returns "You spit in the goblin's face!"</li>
062 *     <li>When userName is {@code "the goblin"}, userTrait is {@code NounTrait.MALE_GENDER}, and targetTrait is
063 *     {@code NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR}, this returns "The goblin spits in your face!"</li>
064 *     <li>When userTrait is {@code NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR}, targetName is {@code "the goblins"}, and
065 *     targetTrait is {@code NounTrait.GROUP}, this returns "You spit in the goblins' faces!"</li>
066 *     <li>When userName is {@code "the goblins"}, userTrait is {@code NounTrait.GROUP}, and targetTrait is
067 *     {@code NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR}, this returns "The goblins spit in your face!"</li>
068 * </ul>
069 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 10/31/2016.
070 */
071public class Messaging {
072
073    /**
074     * Properties of nouns needed to correctly conjugate those nouns and refer to them with pronouns, such as genders.
075     * Includes parts of speech, which only are concerned with whether they refer to a singular noun or a plural noun,
076     * and genders for when a gendered pronoun is needed. This provides substantial support for uncommon cases regarding
077     * gender and pronoun preferences. That said, gender and pronoun preference can be incredibly hard to handle.
078     * The simplest cases are for first- and second-person pronouns; here we have "I/me/my/myself" for
079     * {@link #FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR}, "you/you/your/yourself" for {@link #SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR},
080     * "we/us/our/ourselves" for {@link #FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL}, and "you/you/your/yourselves" for
081     * {@link #SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL}; there are more pronouns this can produce, but they aren't listed here.
082     * Third-person pronouns are considerably more challenging because English sporadically considers gender as part of
083     * conjugation, but doesn't provide a universally-acceptable set of gendered pronouns.
084     * <br>
085     * This at least tries to provide pronoun handling for the common cases, such as "you" not needing a gendered
086     * pronoun at all (it uses {@link #SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR}), and supports {@link #MALE_GENDER male},
087     * {@link #FEMALE_GENDER female}, {@link #NO_GENDER genderless} (using "it" and related forms; preferred especially
088     * for things that aren't alive, and in most cases not recommended for people),
089     * {@link #UNSPECIFIED_GENDER "unspecified"} (using "they" in place of "he" or "she"; preferred in some cases when
090     * describing someone with a non-specific gender or an unknown gender) pronouns, and {@link #GROUP group} for when a
091     * group of individuals, regardless of gender or genders, is referred to with a single pronoun. As mentioned, this
092     * has support for some uncommon situations, like {@link #ADDITIONAL_GENDER additional gender} (as in, a gender that
093     * is in addition to male and female but that is not genderless, which has a clear use case when describing
094     * non-human species, and a more delicate use for humans who use non-binary gender pronouns; hopefully "xe" will be
095     * acceptable), and finally a {@link #SPECIAL_CASE_GENDER "special case"} pronoun that is unpronounceable and, if
096     * given special processing, can be used as a replacement target for customized pronouns. For the additional gender,
097     * the non-binary gendered pronouns are modified from the male pronouns by replacing 'h' with 'x' (he becomes xe,
098     * his becomes xis). The "special case" pronouns replace the 'h' in the male pronouns with 'qvq', except for in one
099     * case. Where, if the female pronoun were used, it would be "hers", but the male pronoun in that case would be "his",
100     * changing the male pronoun would lead to a difficult-to-replace case because "his" is also used in the case where
101     * the female pronoun is the usefully distinct "her". Here, the "special case" gender diverges from what it usually
102     * does, and uses "qvqims" in place of "his" or "hers". The "special case" pronouns should be replaced before being
103     * displayed, since they look like gibberish or a glitch and so are probably confusing out of context.
104     */
105    public enum NounTrait {
106        /**
107         * As in, "I am my own boss." Doesn't reference gender.
108         * <br>
109         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
110         * <br>
111         * I/my/I/me/my/mine/myself
112         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "I hurry".
113         * Does not pluralize.
114         */
115        FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR,
116        /**
117         * As in, "You are your own boss." Doesn't reference gender.
118         * <br>
119         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
120         * <br>
121         * you/your/you/you/your/yours/yourself
122         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "you hurry".
123         * Does not pluralize.
124         */
125        SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR,
126        /**
127         * As in, "We are our own bosses." Doesn't reference gender, and applies to groups.
128         * <br>
129         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
130         * <br>
131         * we/our/we/us/our/ours/ourselves
132         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "we hurry".
133         * Pluralizes.
134         */
135        FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL,
136        /**
137         * As in, "You are your own bosses." Doesn't reference gender, and applies to groups.
138         * <br>
139         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
140         * <br>
141         * you/your/you/you/your/yours/yourselves
142         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "you hurry".
143         * Pluralizes.
144         */
145        SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL,
146        /**
147         * Inanimate objects or beings without gender, as in "It is its own boss."
148         * <br>
149         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
150         * <br>
151         * Name/Name's/it/it/its/its/itself
152         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "it hurries".
153         * Does not pluralize.
154         */
155        NO_GENDER,
156        /**
157         * Male pronoun preference, as in "He is his own boss."
158         * <br>
159         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
160         * <br>
161         * Name/Name's/he/he/his/his/himself
162         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "he hurries".
163         * Does not pluralize.
164         */
165        MALE_GENDER,
166        /**
167         * Female pronoun preference, as in "She is her own boss."
168         * <br>
169         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
170         * <br>
171         * Name/Name's/she/she/her/hers/herself
172         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "she hurries".
173         * Does not pluralize.
174         */
175        FEMALE_GENDER,
176        /**
177         * "Singular they" pronoun preference or to be used when preference is unknown, as in "They are their own boss."
178         * <br>
179         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
180         * <br>
181         * Name/Name's/they/them/their/theirs/themself
182         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "they hurry".
183         * Does not pluralize.
184         */
185        UNSPECIFIED_GENDER,
186        /**
187         * Third-gender pronoun preference, potentially relevant for cultures with non-binary gender terms. As in, "Xe
188         * is xis own boss."
189         * <br>
190         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
191         * <br>
192         * Name/Name's/xe/xim/xis/xis/ximself
193         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "xe hurries".
194         * Does not pluralize.
195         */
196        ADDITIONAL_GENDER,
197        /**
198         * Unpronounceable words that can be processed specially for more complex cases of pronoun preference. As in,
199         * "Qvqe is qvqis own boss."
200         * <br>
201         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
202         * <br>
203         * Name/Name's/qvqe/qvqim/qvqis/qvqims/qvqimself
204         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "qvqe hurries".
205         * Does not pluralize.
206         */
207        SPECIAL_CASE_GENDER,
208        /**
209         * Any third-person plural, as in "They are their own bosses." Not to be confused with UNSPECIFIED_GENDER, which
210         * is for singular beings, but usually uses "they" in the same way (not always).
211         * <br>
212         * name/name_s/i/me/my/mine/myself
213         * <br>
214         * Name/Name's/they/them/their/theirs/themselves
215         * "^i hurr^$$$" becomes "they hurry".
216         * Pluralizes.
217         */
218        GROUP;
219
220        public String nameText(String term) {
221            switch (this) {
222                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
223                    return "I";
224                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
225                    return "we";
226                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
227                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
228                    return "you";
229                default:
230                    return term;
231            }
232        }
233        public String name_sText(String term) {
234            switch (this) {
235                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
236                    return "my";
237                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
238                    return "our";
239                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
240                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
241                    return "your";
242                default:
243                    if(term.isEmpty()) return "";
244                    else if(term.endsWith("s")) return term + '\'';
245                    else return term + "'s";
246            }
247        }
248
249        public String iText() {
250            switch (this) {
251                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
252                    return "I";
253                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
254                    return "we";
255                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
256                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
257                    return "you";
258                case NO_GENDER:
259                    return "it";
260                case MALE_GENDER:
261                    return "he";
262                case FEMALE_GENDER:
263                    return "she";
264                //case UNSPECIFIED_GENDER: return "they";
265                case ADDITIONAL_GENDER:
266                    return "xe";
267                case SPECIAL_CASE_GENDER:
268                    return "qvqe";
269                default:
270                    return "they";
271            }
272        }
273        public String meText() {
274            switch (this) {
275                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
276                    return "me";
277                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
278                    return "us";
279                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
280                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
281                    return "you";
282                case NO_GENDER:
283                    return "it";
284                case MALE_GENDER:
285                    return "him";
286                case FEMALE_GENDER:
287                    return "her";
288                //case UNSPECIFIED_GENDER: return "them";
289                case ADDITIONAL_GENDER:
290                    return "xim";
291                case SPECIAL_CASE_GENDER:
292                    return "qvqim";
293                default:
294                    return "them";
295            }
296        }
297
298        public String myText() {
299            switch (this) {
300                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
301                    return "my";
302                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
303                    return "our";
304                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
305                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
306                    return "your";
307                case NO_GENDER:
308                    return "its";
309                case MALE_GENDER:
310                    return "his";
311                case FEMALE_GENDER:
312                    return "her";
313                //case UNSPECIFIED_GENDER: return "their";
314                case ADDITIONAL_GENDER:
315                    return "xis";
316                case SPECIAL_CASE_GENDER:
317                    return "qvqis";
318                default:
319                    return "their";
320            }
321        }
322        public String mineText() {
323            switch (this) {
324                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
325                    return "mine";
326                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
327                    return "ours";
328                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
329                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
330                    return "yours";
331                case NO_GENDER:
332                    return "its";
333                case MALE_GENDER:
334                    return "his";
335                case FEMALE_GENDER:
336                    return "hers";
337                //case UNSPECIFIED_GENDER: return "theirs";
338                case ADDITIONAL_GENDER:
339                    return "xis";
340                case SPECIAL_CASE_GENDER:
341                    return "qvqims";
342                default:
343                    return "theirs";
344            }
345        }
346
347        public String myselfText() {
348            switch (this) {
349                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
350                    return "myself";
351                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
352                    return "ourselves";
353                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
354                    return "yourself";
355                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
356                    return "yourselves";
357                case NO_GENDER:
358                    return "itself";
359                case MALE_GENDER:
360                    return "himself";
361                case FEMALE_GENDER:
362                    return "herself";
363                case UNSPECIFIED_GENDER:
364                    return "themself";
365                case ADDITIONAL_GENDER:
366                    return "ximself";
367                case SPECIAL_CASE_GENDER:
368                    return "qvqimself";
369                default:
370                    return "themselves";
371            }
372        }
373
374        public String sText() {
375            switch (this) {
376                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
377                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
378                case GROUP:
379                    return "s";
380                default:
381                    return "";
382            }
383        }
384        public String ssText() {
385            switch (this) {
386                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
387                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
388                case GROUP:
389                    return "es";
390                default:
391                    return "";
392            }
393        }
394        public String sssText() {
395            switch (this) {
396                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
397                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
398                case GROUP:
399                    return "ies";
400                default:
401                    return "y";
402            }
403        }
404        public String usiText() {
405            switch (this) {
406                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
407                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
408                case GROUP:
409                    return "i";
410                default:
411                    return "us";
412            }
413        }
414        public String fvesText() {
415            switch (this) {
416                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
417                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
418                case GROUP:
419                    return "ves";
420                default:
421                    return "f";
422            }
423        }
424
425        public String $Text() {
426            switch (this) {
427                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
428                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
429                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
430                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
431                case UNSPECIFIED_GENDER:
432                case GROUP:
433                    return "";
434                default:
435                    return "s";
436            }
437        }
438        public String $$Text() {
439            switch (this) {
440                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
441                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
442                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
443                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
444                case UNSPECIFIED_GENDER:
445                case GROUP:
446                    return "";
447                default:
448                    return "es";
449            }
450        }
451        public String $$$Text() {
452            switch (this) {
453                case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
454                case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
455                case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
456                case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
457                case UNSPECIFIED_GENDER:
458                case GROUP:
459                    return "y";
460                default:
461                    return "ies";
462            }
463        }
464
465        public String directText(String term) {
466            return term;
467        }
468
469    }
470
471    public static class Group
472    {
473        public String[] members;
474
475        public Group()
476        {
477            members = new String[]{"the goblin", "the dragon", "the warlock"};
478        }
479        public Group(String... members)
480        {
481            this.members = members;
482        }
483    }
484
485
486    /**
487     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
488     * conjugated terms for the given user and their associated NounTrait.
489     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@" or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
490     * @param user the name of the user for cases where it can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
491     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
492     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
493     */
494    public static String transform(CharSequence message, String user, NounTrait userTrait)
495    {
496        Replacer ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(user, userTrait, true));
497        return ur.replace(message);
498    }
499
500    /**
501     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
502     * conjugated terms for the given group of users and that group's associated NounTrait. The NounTrait only matters
503     * if it is first-person or second-person (in which case this uses the plural form) or if the Group contains one
504     * member (in which case it uses any gendered pronouns specified by userTrait); it uses {@link NounTrait#GROUP} in
505     * any other case.
506     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@" or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
507     * @param user a {@link Group} of users (a String array) for cases where it can replace text, like "@" or "@Name"
508     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
509     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
510     */
511    public static String transform(CharSequence message, Group user, NounTrait userTrait)
512    {
513        Replacer ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(userTrait, true, user.members));
514        return ur.replace(message);
515    }
516
517    /**
518     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
519     * conjugated terms for the given user, their associated NounTrait, the given target, and their NounTrait.
520     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@", "^", or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
521     * @param user the name of the user for cases where it can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
522     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
523     * @param target the name of the target for cases where it can replace text like "^" or "^Name"
524     * @param targetTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how the target should be referred to
525     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
526     */
527    public static String transform(CharSequence message, String user, NounTrait userTrait, String target, NounTrait targetTrait)
528    {
529        Replacer tr = new Replacer(targetPattern, new BeingSubstitution(target, targetTrait, false)),
530                ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(user, userTrait, true));
531        return ur.replace(tr.replace(message));
532    }
533
534    /**
535     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
536     * conjugated terms for the given Group of users, that group's associated NounTrait, the given target, and their
537     * NounTrait. The NounTrait for user only matters if it is first-person or second-person (in which case this uses
538     * the plural form) or if the Group contains one member (in which case it uses any gendered pronouns specified by
539     * userTrait); it uses {@link NounTrait#GROUP} in any other case.
540     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@", "^", or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
541     * @param user the {@link Group} of users for cases where they can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
542     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
543     * @param target the name of the target for cases where it can replace text like "^" or "^Name"
544     * @param targetTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how the target should be referred to
545     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
546     */
547    public static String transform(CharSequence message, Group user, NounTrait userTrait, String target, NounTrait targetTrait)
548    {
549        Replacer tr = new Replacer(targetPattern, new BeingSubstitution(target, targetTrait, false)),
550                ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(userTrait, true, user.members));
551        return ur.replace(tr.replace(message));
552    }
553
554    /**
555     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
556     * conjugated terms for the given Group of users, that group's associated NounTrait, the given group of targets, and
557     * that group's NounTrait. The NounTraits only matter if they are is first-person or second-person (in which case
558     * this uses the plural form) or if a Group contains one member (in which case it uses any gendered pronouns
559     * specified by userTrait or targetTrait); it uses {@link NounTrait#GROUP} in any other case.
560     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@", "^", or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
561     * @param user the {@link Group} of users for cases where they can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
562     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
563     * @param target the {@link Group} of targets for cases where they can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
564     * @param targetTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how the target should be referred to
565     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
566     */
567    public static String transform(CharSequence message, Group user, NounTrait userTrait, Group target, NounTrait targetTrait)
568    {
569        Replacer tr = new Replacer(targetPattern, new BeingSubstitution(targetTrait, false, target.members)),
570                ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(userTrait, true, user.members));
571        return ur.replace(tr.replace(message));
572    }
573
574
575    /**
576     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
577     * conjugated terms for the given user, that user's associated NounTrait, the given Group of targets, and that
578     * group's NounTrait. The NounTrait for target only matters if it is first-person or second-person (in which case
579     * this uses the plural form) or if the Group contains one member (in which case it uses any gendered pronouns
580     * specified by targetTrait); it uses {@link NounTrait#GROUP} in any other case.
581     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@", "^", or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
582     * @param user the name of the user for cases where it can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
583     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
584     * @param target the {@link Group} of targets for cases where they can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
585     * @param targetTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how the target should be referred to
586     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
587     */
588    public static String transform(CharSequence message, String user, NounTrait userTrait, Group target, NounTrait targetTrait)
589    {
590        Replacer tr = new Replacer(targetPattern, new BeingSubstitution(targetTrait, false, target.members)),
591                ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(user, userTrait, true));
592        return ur.replace(tr.replace(message));
593    }
594
595    /**
596     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
597     * conjugated terms for the given user, their associated NounTrait, the given target, and their NounTrait. Also
598     * replaces the nth occurrence of "~" with the matching nth item in extra, so the first "~" is replaced with the
599     * first item in extra, the second "~" with the second item, and so on until one is exhausted.
600     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@", "^", "$", or "~" in it, at least, to be replaced
601     * @param user the name of the user for cases where it can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
602     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
603     * @param target the name of the target for cases where it can replace text like "^" or "^Name"
604     * @param targetTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how the target should be referred to
605     * @param extra an array or vararg of String where the nth item in extra will replace the nth occurrence of "~"
606     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
607     */
608    public static String transform(CharSequence message, String user, NounTrait userTrait, String target, NounTrait targetTrait, String... extra)
609    {
610        Replacer tr = new Replacer(targetPattern, new BeingSubstitution(target, targetTrait, false)),
611                ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(user, userTrait, true));
612        String text = ur.replace(tr.replace(message));
613        if(extra != null && extra.length > 0)
614        {
615            for (int i = 0; i < extra.length; i++) {
616                text = text.replaceFirst("~", extra[i]);
617            }
618        }
619        return text;
620    }
621
622    /**
623     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
624     * conjugated terms for the given Group of users, that group's associated NounTrait, the given target, and their
625     * NounTrait. Also replaces the nth occurrence of "~" with the matching nth item in extra, so the first "~" is
626     * replaced with the first item in extra, the second "~" with the second item, and so on until one is exhausted. The
627     * NounTrait for user only matters if it is first-person or second-person (in which case this uses the plural form)
628     * or if the Group contains one member (in which case it uses any gendered pronouns specified by userTrait); it uses
629     * {@link NounTrait#GROUP} in any other case.
630     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@", "^", or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
631     * @param user the {@link Group} of users for cases where they can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
632     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
633     * @param target the name of the target for cases where it can replace text like "^" or "^Name"
634     * @param targetTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how the target should be referred to
635     * @param extra an array or vararg of String where the nth item in extra will replace the nth occurrence of "~"
636     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
637     */
638    public static String transform(CharSequence message, Group user, NounTrait userTrait, String target, NounTrait targetTrait, String... extra)
639    {
640        Replacer tr = new Replacer(targetPattern, new BeingSubstitution(target, targetTrait, false)),
641                ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(userTrait, true, user.members));
642        String text = ur.replace(tr.replace(message));
643        if(extra != null && extra.length > 0)
644        {
645            for (int i = 0; i < extra.length; i++) {
646                text = text.replaceFirst("~", extra[i]);
647            }
648        }
649        return text;
650    }
651
652    /**
653     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
654     * conjugated terms for the given Group of users, that group's associated NounTrait, the given group of targets, and
655     * that group's NounTrait. Also replaces the nth occurrence of "~" with the matching nth item in extra, so the first
656     * "~" is replaced with the first item in extra, the second "~" with the second item, and so on until one is
657     * exhausted. The NounTraits only matter if they are is first-person or second-person (in which case
658     * this uses the plural form) or if a Group contains one member (in which case it uses any gendered pronouns
659     * specified by userTrait or targetTrait); it uses {@link NounTrait#GROUP} in any other case.
660     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@", "^", or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
661     * @param user the {@link Group} of users for cases where they can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
662     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
663     * @param target the {@link Group} of targets for cases where they can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
664     * @param targetTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how the target should be referred to
665     * @param extra an array or vararg of String where the nth item in extra will replace the nth occurrence of "~"
666     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
667     */
668    public static String transform(CharSequence message, Group user, NounTrait userTrait, Group target, NounTrait targetTrait, String... extra)
669    {
670        Replacer tr = new Replacer(targetPattern, new BeingSubstitution(targetTrait, false, target.members)),
671                ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(userTrait, true, user.members));
672        String text = ur.replace(tr.replace(message));
673        if(extra != null && extra.length > 0)
674        {
675            for (int i = 0; i < extra.length; i++) {
676                text = text.replaceFirst("~", extra[i]);
677            }
678        }
679        return text;
680    }
681
682
683    /**
684     * Takes message and replaces any of the special terms this recognizes, like @, ^, and $, with the appropriately-
685     * conjugated terms for the given user, that user's associated NounTrait, the given Group of targets, and that
686     * group's NounTrait. Also replaces the nth occurrence of "~" with the matching nth item in extra, so the first "~"
687     * is replaced with the first item in extra, the second "~" with the second item, and so on until one is exhausted.
688     * The NounTrait for target only matters if it is first-person or second-person (in which case this uses the plural
689     * form) or if the Group contains one member (in which case it uses any gendered pronouns specified by targetTrait);
690     * it uses {@link NounTrait#GROUP} in any other case.
691     * @param message the message to transform; should contain "@", "^", or "$" in it, at least, to be replaced
692     * @param user the name of the user for cases where it can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
693     * @param userTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how user should be referred to
694     * @param target the {@link Group} of targets for cases where they can replace text like "@" or "@Name"
695     * @param targetTrait the {@link NounTrait} enum that determines how the target should be referred to
696     * @param extra an array or vararg of String where the nth item in extra will replace the nth occurrence of "~"
697     * @return a String resulting from the processing of message
698     */
699    public static String transform(CharSequence message, String user, NounTrait userTrait, Group target, NounTrait targetTrait, String... extra)
700    {
701        Replacer tr = new Replacer(targetPattern, new BeingSubstitution(targetTrait, false, target.members)),
702                ur = new Replacer(userPattern, new BeingSubstitution(user, userTrait, true));
703        String text = ur.replace(tr.replace(message));
704        if(extra != null && extra.length > 0)
705        {
706            for (int i = 0; i < extra.length; i++) {
707                text = text.replaceFirst("~", extra[i]);
708            }
709        }
710        return text;
711    }
712
713
714    protected static final Pattern
715            userPattern = Pattern.compile("({at_sign}\\\\@)|({caret_sign}\\\\\\^)|({dollar_sign}\\\\\\$)|({tilde_sign}\\\\~)|" +
716            "({$$$}\\$\\$\\$)|({$$}\\$\\$)|({$}\\$)|({sss}@sss\\b)|({ss}@ss\\b)|({s}@s\\b)|({usi}@usi\\b)|({fves}@fves\\b)|" +
717            "({name_s}@name_s\\b)|({Name_s}@Name_s\\b)|({name}@name\\b)|({Name}@Name\\b)|({i}@i\\b)|({I}@I\\b)|({me}@me\\b)|({Me}@Me\\b)|" +
718            "({myself}@myself\\b)|({Myself}@Myself\\b)|({my}@my\\b)|({My}@My\\b)|({mine}@mine\\b)|({Mine}@Mine\\b)|({direct}@direct\\b)|" +
719            "({Direct}@Direct\\b)|(?:@({Other}\\p{Lu}\\w*)\\b)|(?:@({other}\\p{Ll}\\w*)\\b)|({=name}@)"),
720            targetPattern = Pattern.compile("({at_sign}\\\\@)|({caret_sign}\\\\\\^)|({dollar_sign}\\\\\\$)|({tilde_sign}\\\\~)|" +
721                    "({$$$}\\^\\$\\$\\$)|({$$}\\^\\$\\$)|({$}\\^\\$)|({sss}\\^sss\\b)|({ss}\\^ss\\b)|({s}\\^s\\b)|({usi}\\^usi\\b)|({fves}\\^fves\\b)|" +
722                    "({name_s}\\^name_s\\b)|({Name_s}\\^Name_s\\b)|({name}\\^name\\b)|({Name}\\^Name\\b)|({i}\\^i\\b)|({I}\\^I\\b)|({me}\\^me\\b)|({Me}\\^Me\\b)|" +
723                    "({myself}\\^myself\\b)|({Myself}\\^Myself\\b)|({my}\\^my\\b)|({My}\\^My\\b)|({mine}\\^mine\\b)|({Mine}\\^Mine\\b)|({direct}^direct\\b)|" +
724                    "({Direct}^Direct\\b)|(?:\\^({Other}\\p{Lu}\\w*)\\b)|(?:\\^({other}\\p{Ll}\\w*)\\b)|({=name}\\^)");
725
726    private static final HashMap<String, String[]> irregular = new HashMap<>(64);
727
728    /**
729     * Adds a given {@code word}, which should start with a lower-case letter and use lower-case letters and underscores
730     * only, to the dictionary this stores. The 6 additional arguments are used for first person singular ("I am"),
731     * first person plural ("we are"), second person singular ("you are"), second person plural ("you are", the same
732     * as the last one usually, but not always), third person singular ("he is"), third person plural ("they are").
733     * @param word the word to learn; must start with a letter and use only lower-case letters and underscores
734     * @param firstPersonSingular the conjugated form of the word for first-person singular ("I do", "I am")
735     * @param firstPersonPlural the conjugated form of the word for first-person plural ("we do", "we are")
736     * @param secondPersonSingular the conjugated form of the word for second-person singular ("you do", "you are")
737     * @param secondPersonPlural the conjugated form of the word for second-person plural ("you do", "you are")
738     * @param thirdPersonSingular the conjugated form of the word for third-person singular ("he does", "he is")
739     * @param thirdPersonPlural the conjugated form of the word for third-person plural and unspecified-gender singular ("they do", "they are")
740     */
741    public static void learnIrregularWord(String word, String firstPersonSingular, String firstPersonPlural,
742                                          String secondPersonSingular, String secondPersonPlural,
743                                          String thirdPersonSingular, String thirdPersonPlural)
744    {
745        irregular.put(word, new String[]{firstPersonSingular, firstPersonPlural, secondPersonSingular, secondPersonPlural,
746                thirdPersonSingular, thirdPersonSingular, thirdPersonSingular, thirdPersonPlural, thirdPersonSingular, thirdPersonSingular,
747                thirdPersonPlural});
748    }
749
750    static {
751        learnIrregularWord("m", "'m", "'re", "'re", "'re", "'s", "'re");
752        learnIrregularWord("am", "am", "are", "are", "are", "is", "are");
753        learnIrregularWord("ve", "'ve", "'ve", "'ve", "'ve", "'s", "'ve");
754        learnIrregularWord("have", "have", "have", "have", "have", "has", "have");
755        learnIrregularWord("haven_t", "haven't", "haven't", "haven't", "haven't", "hasn't", "haven't");
756        learnIrregularWord("do", "do", "do", "do", "do", "does", "do");
757        learnIrregularWord("don_t", "don't", "don't", "don't", "don't", "doesn't", "don't");
758        learnIrregularWord("this", "this", "these", "this", "these", "this", "these");
759    }
760
761    protected static class BeingSubstitution implements Substitution {
762
763        public String term;
764        public NounTrait trait;
765        public boolean finisher;
766        public BeingSubstitution()
767        {
768            term = "Joe";
769            trait = NounTrait.MALE_GENDER;
770            finisher = true;
771        }
772
773        public BeingSubstitution(String term, NounTrait trait, boolean finish)
774        {
775            this.term = (term == null) ? "Nullberoth of the North" : term;
776            this.trait = (trait == null) ? NounTrait.UNSPECIFIED_GENDER : trait;
777            finisher = finish;
778        }
779        public BeingSubstitution(NounTrait firstTrait, boolean finish, String... terms) {
780            int len;
781            if (terms == null || (len = terms.length) <= 0) {
782                term = "Nihilatia of Voidetica";
783                trait = (firstTrait == null) ? NounTrait.UNSPECIFIED_GENDER : firstTrait;
784                finisher = finish;
785            } else if (len == 1) {
786                term = (terms[0] == null) ? "Nullberoth of the North" : terms[0];
787                trait = NounTrait.UNSPECIFIED_GENDER;
788                finisher = finish;
789            } else if (len == 2) {
790                term = terms[0] + " and " + terms[1];
791                if (firstTrait == null)
792                    trait = NounTrait.GROUP;
793                else {
794                    switch (firstTrait) {
795                        case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
796                        case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
797                            trait = NounTrait.FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL;
798                            break;
799                        case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
800                        case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
801                            trait = NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL;
802                            break;
803                        default:
804                            trait = NounTrait.GROUP;
805                    }
806                }
807                finisher = finish;
808            } else {
809                StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder().append(terms[0]).append(", ");
810                for (int i = 1; i < len - 1; i++) {
811                    sb.append(terms[i]).append(", ");
812                }
813                term = sb.append("and ").append(terms[len - 1]).toString();
814                if (firstTrait == null)
815                    trait = NounTrait.GROUP;
816                else {
817                    switch (firstTrait) {
818                        case FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL:
819                        case FIRST_PERSON_SINGULAR:
820                            trait = NounTrait.FIRST_PERSON_PLURAL;
821                            break;
822                        case SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL:
823                        case SECOND_PERSON_SINGULAR:
824                            trait = NounTrait.SECOND_PERSON_PLURAL;
825                            break;
826                        default:
827                            trait = NounTrait.GROUP;
828                    }
829                }
830                finisher = finish;
831
832            }
833        }
834        public static void appendCapitalized(String s, TextBuffer dest)
835        {
836            dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(s.charAt(0)));
837            if(s.length() > 1)
838                dest.append(s.substring(1));
839        }
840        @Override
841        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
842            if(match.isCaptured("at_sign"))
843            {
844                dest.append(finisher ? "@" : "\\@");
845            }
846            else if(match.isCaptured("caret_sign"))
847            {
848                dest.append(finisher ? "^" : "\\^");
849            }
850            else if(match.isCaptured("dollar_sign"))
851            {
852                dest.append(finisher ? "$" : "\\$");
853            }
854            else if(match.isCaptured("tilde_sign"))
855            {
856                dest.append(finisher ? "~" : "\\~");
857            }
858            else if(match.isCaptured("name"))
859            {
860                dest.append(trait.nameText(term));
861            }
862            else if(match.isCaptured("Name"))
863            {
864                appendCapitalized(trait.nameText(term), dest);
865            }
866            else if(match.isCaptured("name_s"))
867            {
868                dest.append(trait.name_sText(term));
869            }
870            else if(match.isCaptured("Name_s"))
871            {
872                appendCapitalized(trait.name_sText(term), dest);
873            }
874            else if(match.isCaptured("i"))
875            {
876                dest.append(trait.iText());
877            }
878            else if(match.isCaptured("I"))
879            {
880                appendCapitalized(trait.iText(), dest);
881            }
882            else if(match.isCaptured("me"))
883            {
884                dest.append(trait.meText());
885            }
886            else if(match.isCaptured("Me"))
887            {
888                appendCapitalized(trait.meText(), dest);
889            }
890            else if(match.isCaptured("my"))
891            {
892                dest.append(trait.myText());
893            }
894            else if(match.isCaptured("My"))
895            {
896                appendCapitalized(trait.myText(), dest);
897            }
898            else if(match.isCaptured("mine"))
899            {
900                dest.append(trait.mineText());
901            }
902            else if(match.isCaptured("Mine"))
903            {
904                appendCapitalized(trait.mineText(), dest);
905            }
906            else if(match.isCaptured("myself"))
907            {
908                dest.append(trait.myselfText());
909            }
910            else if(match.isCaptured("Myself"))
911            {
912                appendCapitalized(trait.myselfText(), dest);
913            }
914            else if(match.isCaptured("s"))
915            {
916                dest.append(trait.sText());
917            }
918            else if(match.isCaptured("ss"))
919            {
920                dest.append(trait.ssText());
921            }
922            else if(match.isCaptured("sss"))
923            {
924                dest.append(trait.sssText());
925            }
926            else if(match.isCaptured("usi"))
927            {
928                dest.append(trait.usiText());
929            }
930            else if(match.isCaptured("fves"))
931            {
932                dest.append(trait.fvesText());
933            }
934            else if(match.isCaptured("$"))
935            {
936                dest.append(trait.$Text());
937            }
938            else if(match.isCaptured("$$"))
939            {
940                dest.append(trait.$$Text());
941            }
942            else if(match.isCaptured("$$$"))
943            {
944                dest.append(trait.$$$Text());
945            }
946            else if(match.isCaptured("other"))
947            {
948                String[] others = irregular.get(match.group("other"));
949                if(others != null && others.length == 11)
950                    dest.append(others[trait.ordinal()]);
951                else
952                    match.getGroup(0, dest);
953            }
954            else if(match.isCaptured("Other"))
955            {
956                String[] others = irregular.get(match.group("Other").toLowerCase());
957                if(others != null && others.length == 11)
958                    appendCapitalized(others[trait.ordinal()], dest);
959                else
960                    match.getGroup(0, dest);
961            }
962            else if(match.isCaptured("direct"))
963            {
964                dest.append(trait.directText(term));
965            }
966            else if(match.isCaptured("Direct"))
967            {
968                appendCapitalized(trait.directText(term), dest);
969            }
970            else
971                match.getGroup(0, dest);
972        }
973    }
974}
